We know that companies are in the midst of a major battle for digital talent. There is a higher demand for exceptional candidates than there ever has been before, business leaders have to create strategies to retain their talent.  At HyperionDev we understand this and we are positioned to provide tailored and bespoke solutions to our employer partners to help them stay ahead of the competition. We also support your organisation's skills development and B-BBEE scorecard needs with our MICT SETA accredited training skills programme.  If you’d like to know more about our corporate service offering please visit our page. Learn more: https://bit.ly/3t1PNXA

Introducing Aslam, our Business Development Manager at HyperionDev.  Covid-19 has catapulted digital transformation and with transformation comes change management. We at HyperionDev believe that human beings are the enablers of both technology and change. We hold the unshakable belief that machines can’t match humans and that people are the best teachers and reviewers of code. We envision a future where anyone can affordably learn to #writecoderight by having access to human-led tech education.    Steve Jobs said, “Technology is nothing. What's important is that you have faith in people, that they're basically good and smart — and if you give them tools (tech), they'll do wonderful things with them". We at HyperionDev have faith in your skills force, we teach them to code and by virtue of an equal universe they excel in your organisation.  Please reach out to Aslam for any corporate training needs: aslamk@hyperiondev.com  If you’d like to know more about our corporate service, Learn more: https://bit.ly/3sOJHtd
We have some exciting news to share! 🎉  We’re launching a new coding bootcamp with University of Cape Town & Law@Work! 😎  Learn more: https://bit.ly/3sNJo1V

Introducing Rudi, our Business Development and Relationships Manager at HyperionDev.  “If you don’t evolve, you’ll evaporate”... this is more true now than ever before - in the era of the Great Resignation, it’s imperative for organizations to prioritize skills development in the workplace. No longer seen as a perk, but a must.  At HyperionDev we’ve made it our mission to help close the global tech-skills gap by offering tech-focused programs assisting companies to remain competitive by enabling their teams to thrive while retaining top talent. We believe coding is for everyone!  Please reach out to Rudi for any corporate training needs: rudim@hyperiondev.com  If you’d like to know more about our corporate service, Learn more: https://bit.ly/3LLx9vy

After an action-packed 2021, HyperionDev is in for an equally exciting 2022 🎉  In 2021, we closed the largest edtech crowdfunding campaign of the year and the largest crowdfund ever for an African-linked startup, having to close our campaign 3 weeks due to overwhelming demand.   After partnering with some of the world’s top universities to help scale new online programmes, we’ve raised more than £2mil (R40mil)  in new funding, and have decided to crowdfund again in 2022.  Pre-register now for our upcoming Crowdfund at https://bit.ly/3sFuXx0 to get early exclusive access to invest in us next week - investments are accepted on a first-come, first-served basis, and we’re nearly already at our limit of pre-registrations.  *Capital at risk. Invest aware.

It's 2021 and women are still underrepresented in tech. A recent PwC #WomeninTech report found that at the top 10 global tech companies, only 19% of tech-related roles were held by women. What's more, women made up a mere 28% of their senior leadership, relative to the 72% male leadership.   In our latest blog post, we interrogate this gender disparity that is commonplace in the local and global tech industry to understand the key challenges at play as well as what steps we can take to ensure that the world of tech is a more accessible and equitable place.   Read more on the blog: https://bit.ly/3d4uzRG

As a trying year edges towards a close, keeping motivations up can be tough. ⭐ Happy Women’s Day in South Africa! Shoutout to these powerful women at HyperionDev who are all dedicated to closing the tech skills gap. ⭐

Women's Day is tomorrow and we're celebrating some of our favorite ladies at HyperionDev. Meet Phoebe, our data analysis intern. Check out what she has to say about being a female in the tech industry:   "Growing up, I’ve always been fascinated by STEM and cool tech innovations. As I got older, I started to think more about how technology can help people improve their lives, especially those in third world countries. I decided to pursue a career in data science because it affords me the freedom to apply my skills in virtually any sector I want.  From an early age, the gender stereotypes of “boys are better at STEM subjects than girls” dampened my motivation towards my studies. It took great commitment to be able to push myself into the tech industry; but what really helped me the most was the empowerment from other women and girls in tech.   I’ve learned a lot from the experiences of the women before me, and I hope by being where I’m at now, I can help younger girls remember that they are just as capable as anyone else."

✨ Leading up to Women's Day this Friday, we're showcasing some of our favorite ladies at HyperionDev. Meet Mikha, one of our software engineers. Check out what she has to say about being a female in the tech industry:   "I decided to pursue [a tech career] as it seemed flexible and engaging enough to adapt to whatever future I was heading towards.  I think the biggest [challenge for me] is imposter syndrome - the belief that you don't belong or don't know what you are doing and that it is a mistake you were given the job in the first place. This is a problem amongst many people in tech, but particularly women.  But at some point you figure out what you are good at and how to ask for help on the things you're bad at. Eventually, you realise no one really knows what they're doing and we are all just trying our best.  My advice is to not undervalue yourself. Apply for the jobs you think you are under-qualified for, ask for the salary you actually deserve, and speak up in meetings when you have something to say."

Did you know? The first programmer was a woman!  In 1843, Ada Lovelace, a British mathematician, translated an Italian article on an Analytical Engine and added her own notes. These notes described an algorithm for the Analytical Engine to compute Bernoulli numbers which was specifically meant to be implemented on a computer, thus deeming her the first programmer.   #WCW #FirstProgrammer #CodeLife #Programming #Hyperiondev  https://ibb.co/iEDoLa

Did you know? The first computer bug was a REAL BUG!  A moth that got stuck in the relay of a Mark II Computer in 1947. It was recorded by Grace Hopper who stated that the bug was hindering operation of the machine and needed to be ‘debugged’. On her notes she wrote, “first  actual case of a bug being found’ and this popularized the terms we know today.   #Bug #CodeLife #Programming #Debugging #Softwaredev  https://ibb.co/khRQyv

NEW WEBSITE LAUNCHED, REGISTER NOW:  www.hyperiondev.com  We're excited to announce that the Hyperion Portal now is live and we encourage all those interesting in FREE online programming courses in Python, Java, or C++ to register now. New features include:   - See our complete course offerings, with feedback on each, before selecting a course of study.   - Gain access to your own unique user area, allowing you to quickly contact your tutor to request marking or help.  - Earn 'Hyperion Stars' by completing optional Tasks, following coding conventions, and implementing efficient solutions. We refer our top users, as measured by Stars, with South African software development companies for internship and part-time roles.  - Get personalised signup instructions for our courses generated automatically, which you can access at any time.  Phase 2 of the portal is expected in February 2015 and will offer the ability for users to see and interact with other students on the same course as them and located near them, information on on-campus tutoring sessions, and new fully online and no-setup required courses!  The development of this platform was made possible thanks to funding from the Python Software Foundation and contributions of numerous members of our team.

Sign up now for a free, online, programming course at www.hyperiondev.com   What has Hyperion achieved in 1 year?  - Delivered free programming courses online and on university campuses to over 650 students from across Southern Africa. Developed courses in the programming languages Python, Java, HTML, C++ and R.  - Raised over R150000 in funding from the University of Edinburgh Development Trust, Santander Bank and the Python Foundation. Established Hyperion teams at 6 universities: University of Johannesburg, Wits, The University of Edinburgh, University of KwaZulu-Natal,  University of Cape Town and the Durban University of Technology.  - Secured funding to expand to 7 more universities such as the Mangosuthu University of Technology and University of Zululand.  Recruited a diverse team of 20 Hyperion Developers from over 100 applicants.  - Installed over 35 Hyperion Computers at 6 educational institutions in joint projects with Ezemvelo KZN Wildlife, Linking Notes, The Jabulani Project, The Turing Trust,  and JumpStart.  - Developed the HyperionOS operating system as a software package to aid Math, Science and IT education in secondary schools.

Hyperion will be offering a new course from January 2013: Java!  This course is intended for teachers and students who need to know Java for the South African NSC Syllabus. The course will be offered at both Beginner (12 tasks) and Intermediate level (8 tasks).  We have also expanded our Python courses (Beginner/Intermediate and Advanced) by adding in two new tasks: a Machine Learning (AI) task and another Natural Language Processing (AI) task planned for February.   You can sign up for any of these FREE courses today at www.hyperiondev.com

Hyperion Developer Edward Chisoro was in Cape Town this week, meeting with representatives of the Manenberg Township Community. Hyperion is collaborating with the Emergency Medicine Society of South Africa to bring a successful emergency medicine programme run in Manenberg to a township in KwaZulu-Natal. This Emergency First Aid Responder programme empowers township communities in South Africa through training locals in basic first aid and emergency medicine. These trained community members, or EFARS, are then dispatched to treat victims of violent crimes in their townships.     Hyperion hopes to work with local government agencies, academics, and township communities in South Africa to see the programme run in KZN.

We're proud to announce that Hyperion has received R60000 (£4200) in funding through an award made to one of our Developers, Riaz Moola, by the University of Edinburgh (Scotland, UK) and Santander Bank. This award is made to students of the University of Edinburgh and was awarded specifically for IT development in South Africa through international collaborations.

Our current Python teaching syllabus:   Task 1 - Introduction to programming in Python  Task 2 - Introduction to Python with more advanced concepts  Task 3 - Bioinformatics in Python with an introduction to Genetics and DNA from a Computer Science perspective  Task 4 - Natural Language Processing in Python using the Natural Language Toolkit. Slides, notes and example exercises adapted used with permission from the University of Edinburgh Informatics department.  Task 5 - Python on the web.Using Python for frameworks like Django and working using Python to generate HTML, Javascript and add dynamic functionality to websites.  Task 6 - Artificial Intelligence. An introduction to Artificial Intelligence with applications to computer game AI using Python.  Task 7 - Cloud Computing. An introduction to the Amazon Cloud. Setting up servers on the cloud, using Ubuntu servers and installed Python to host and create your own free server.  Check out more information at www.rmoola.com/join.html . All lessons are free.
